questions.text: One of the following is associated with sexual asphyxia
questions.solution:
Masochism is associated with sexual asphyxia

In masochism, person gets sexual gratification by infliction of pain on himself or by suffering. In case of sexual asphyxia, the person obtains sexual gratification by hypoxiating himself usually by constriction around the neck (Autoerotic hanging).

Partial hanging can be used as a means to obtain sexual gratification. Failure to release the ligature might lead to asphyxia and death. This is known as sexual asphyxia (autoerotic death).

Option A: Fetichism means the use of fetish for sexual gratification. In this, recurrent, intense sexual fantasies, sexual urges, or behaviour involving the use of living or non-living objects. It is almost exclusively seen in males.

Option C: Sexual oralism is obtaining sexual pleasure from the application of mouth to the sexual organs.

Option D: Necrophagia means sadistic perversion seen among males, who get sexual gratification by tearing out the genitals or other parts like breasts, buttocks, etc., of their partner after her death by his teeth and may virtually eat them raw.

KEY TAKEAWAY - Sexual asphyxia is seen in masochism

Reference:

  • The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 35th edition - Page number:335
  • Review of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology Including Clinical And Pathological Aspects - page number:394, 395

questions.text: Which of the following tests measures ratio of weight of the lungs to the body weight that helps in determination of whether the baby was born alive or not?
questions.solution:
The test that measures the ratio of the weight of the lungs to the body weight that helps in the determination of whether the baby was born alive or not is Plocquet's test.

Plocquet's test: It is based on the ratio of weight of lungs to whole body weight, a respired lung weighs 1/35 of the body weight.


  • Option A: Hydrostatic Test/Floatation Test/Raygat's Test: It is based on the lung changes in a fetus after respiration. On breathing, the volume of the lungs is increased, which more than compensates for the weight of additional blood, due to which specific gravity is diminished. Hence, after respiration, the lung floats in water.
  • Option C: Breslau's second life test: It works on the principle that some air is swallowed during respiration in a live born child and detecting the presence of this air in stomach constitutes the basis for this test.
  • Option D: Wredin's test: Before birth, the middle ear contains gelatinous embryonic connective tissue, not air. With respiration, the eustachian tube opens and air replaces the gelatinous substances in a few hours to five weeks.

KEY TAKEAWAYS--The test that measures the ratio of the weight of the lungs to the body weight that helps in the determination of whether the baby was born alive or not is Plocquet's test.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology 34th Edition - page number: 340, 341, 342

questions.text: A mother died after an illegal abortion by the doctor. Under which section of BNS the doctor can be prosecuted:
questions.solution:
Sec. 90 BNS: - Death caused by act done with intent to cause miscarriage:

(1) Whoever, with intent to cause the miscarriage of a woman with child, does any act which causes the death of such woman, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

(2) Where the act referred to in sub-section (1) is done without the consent of the woman, shall be punishable either with imprisonment for life, or with the punishment specified in said sub-section.

  • "Provided that if the miscarriage is caused after conducting a pre-natal sex determination test of the fetus confirming it to be a female fetus, the person causing the miscarriage shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for life and shall also be liable to a fine which may extend to two lakh rupees".

OPTION A - Sec. 88 BNS: - Causing miscarriage: Whoever voluntarily causes a woman with child to miscarry, shall, if such miscarriage be not caused in good faith for the purpose of saving the life of the woman, be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both; and, if the woman be quick with child, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

Incorrect Options:

OPTION B - Sec. 89 BNS: - Causing miscarriage without woman's consent: Whoever commits the offence under section 88 without the consent of the woman, whether the woman is quick with child or not, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

OPTION D - Sec. 91 BNS: - Act done with intent to prevent child being born alive or to cause to die after birth: Whoever before the birth of any child does any act with the intention of thereby preventing that child from being born alive or causing it to die after its birth, and does by such act prevent that child from being born alive, or causes it to die after its birth, shall, if such act be not caused in good faith for the purpose of saving the life of the mother, be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, or with fine, or with both.

Sec. 92 BNS: - Causing death of quick unborn child by act amounting to culpable homicide: Whoever does any act under such circumstances, that if he thereby caused death he would be guilty of culpable homicide, and does by such act cause the death of a quick unborn child, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- According to Sec. 90 BNS, doctors could be prosecuted if the mother died after an illegal abortion

Reference - Reference: Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhitha, 2023.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child came to the casualty with difficulty in walking and had pain in the perineal region. Anal swabs were taken and showed needle-shaped crystals with Picric acid. What is the test done?
questions.solution:
Due to the presence of spermine (from prostate )in seminal fluid, yellow needle shaped crystals of spermine picrate are formed when treated with picric acid.


Incorrect Options -

Option B - Creatine phosphokinase -Can detect 6 months old semen.

Option C - Acid phosphatase -(Walker test )Done for aspermia. Value >100 bodansky units indicate that ejaculation occured within 12 hours of examination

Option D- Florence Test - Due to presence of choline (seminal vesicle) in seminal fluid, dark brown rhombic crystals of choline iodide appear when treated with Florence reagent


KEY TAKEAWAYS- Due to the presence of spermine (from prostate )in seminal fluid, yellow needle shaped crystals of spermine picrate are formed when treated with picric acid.

Tagline - Easy

Reference:The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition - Page number:434

questions.text: Spalding's sign is seen in?
questions.solution:
Spalding's sign - loss of cranial bone alignment and overlapping of bones. It is the pathognomonic radiological sign of intrauterine death seen after 7 days of death due to liquefaction of brain.

A deadborn child is one which has died in utero and shows one of the following signs after it is completely born:

  • Rigor mortis: Rigor mortis may occur in a dead fetus before birth or at birth.
  • Maceration:
  • Maceration is a process of aseptic autolysis. It occurs when a dead fetus remains in the uterus for 3-4 days surrounded by liquor amnii but with exclusion of air.
  • Skin slippage is the earliest sign (occurs within 12 hours).
  • There is gas in the great vessels and chambers of the heart (Robert's sign).
  • The one important radiological sign suggestive of maceration is Spalding's sign, i.e. skull bones override each other. The smell is somewhat rancid.
  • Putrefaction (decomposition): If the membranes are ruptured after the death of the fetus and air gains entry into the liquor amnii, the fetus undergoes putrefaction instead of maceration. The body is greenish, foul-smelling, and bloated.
  • Mummification: It results when there is deficient blood supply, scanty liquor, and no air enters the uterus. The body is thin, shrivelled, dark brown, and emits a smell like rotten cheese.

Incorrect Options - Spalding sign is not seen with Options A, B and D.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Spalding sign - loss of cranial bone alignment and overlapping of bones. It is the pathognomonic radiological sign of intrauterine death seen after 7 days of death due to liquefaction of brain.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition - Page number:438

questions.text: A child who lives with her grandparents in an old house presents with abdominal pain, anemia, and facial pallor. Which chronic poisoning is suspected in this case?
questions.solution:
• History of living in old houses along with anemia, and abdominal pain points towards lead poisoning
  • Lead inhibits ALA Dehydratase and ferrochelatase resulting in microcytic hypochromic anemia.
  • TIPS AND TRICK for lead poisoning -
  • A- Anemia
  • B-Basophilic stippling
  • C- Colic and constipation "Lead leads to lead lines":
  • D- Drops -Wrist drop and foot drop
  • E- Encephalopathy
  • F-Facial pallor (earliest feature)

Incorrect Options -

Option A-Copper poisoning - Presents with Wilson disease(hepatolenticular degeneration ), burning pain in stomach along with blue green vomitus.

Option C-Mercury poisoning -

  • T- Tremors- course tremors in hands , arms , tongue known as Danbury tremors / Hatter's shake
  • A- Acrodynia -pain and pinkish discoloration of hands and feet.
  • B-Blue black lines on gums
  • L- Lentis -Brown pigment on anterior lens capsule
  • E-Erethism -Psychological disturbance like depression, insomnia etc.

Option D -Arsenic poisoning -Presents with

  • Raindrop pigmentation
  • Hyperkeratosis of palms and soles
  • Aldrich mees lines and garlic odour of breath, alopecia etc.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Abdominal pain, anemia, and facial pallor are features of lead poisoning.

TAGLINE - EASY

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition - Page number:543,544

questions.text: To detect vaginal cells on a person who is accused of rape, which test will you use?
questions.solution:
Lugol's iodine test will be used to detect the vaginal cells present on the penis of a rape accused. It shows brown color on filter paper due to the presence of glycogen in epithelial cells of the vagina.


Incorrect options:

  • Option A: Florence test is used to detect choline in that originates from seminal vesicles. It produces dark brown, rhombic, or needle-shaped crystals of choline iodide if semen is present.

  • Option B: Barberio test is used to detect spermatic fluid. It produces yellow needle shaped crystals of spermine picrate when picric acid is added to spermatic fluid.

  • Option D: Precipitin test is used for species identification of semen stain. A positive test will confirm human origin.

KEY TAKEWAYS- Lugol's iodine test will be used to detect the vaginal cells present on the penis of a rape accused.

TAGLINE-EASY

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition - Page number:434

Hooch tragedy is due to the consumption of cheap illicit liquor containing methanol, particularly by the lower socio-economic classes.

  • The central organ for metabolism is the
  • Methanol or methyl alcohol is first oxidized to formaldehyde with the help of alcohol dehydrogenase. It is further metabolized to formic acid via aldehyde dehydrogenase. These metabolites are responsible for the adverse effects of intoxication.
  • Features seen are ophthalmological complications such as blindness, and optic neuropathy. Brain edema, acute renal failure, and severe metabolic derangement are also seen.

Incorrect Options-

Option A- Phosphorus is a protoplasmic poison, characterized by luminescent vomiting and feces, Smoky stool syndrome, and phossy jaw. It has a garlic-like odour.


Option B - Mercury- It presents as -

  • T- Tremors- course tremors in hands , arms , tongue known as Danbury tremors / Hatter's shake
  • A- Acrodynia -pain and pinkish discoloration of hands and feet.
  • B-Blue black lines on gums
  • L- Lentis -Brown pigment on anterior lens capsule
  • E-Erethism -Psychological disturbance like depression, insomnia etc.

Option C-Alcohol At low concentrations- it causes visual disturbances, mood changes, and loss of coordination. At higher concentrations, it causes Korsakoff psychosis, Wernicke's encephalopathy, machiafava bignami syndrome etc.

KEY TAKEAWAYS-Hooch tragedy is associated with methanol.

TAGLINE-MODERATE

questions.text: Police are chasing a murderer who jumps from a multistoried building to escape. He lands on his feet but dies immediately on the spot. Which of the following skull fractures is most likely to have caused this fatal injury?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, ring fracture is most likely to have caused the fatal injury.

These are the most common fractures that occur due to a fall from height.

These occur in the posterior fossa around the foramen magnum. If the kinetic energy of the fall is not absorbed by fractures of the legs, pelvis, or spine, the impact is transmitted up the cervical spine. This force may be rammed into the skull, carrying a circle of occipital bone with it.


Option A-Ring fracture-Usually caused by fall from height and landing on feet.

Option B- Hinge fracture- Also known as motorcyclist fracture , runs from one petrous ridge to another petrous ridge.


Option c- Spider web fracture -Also known as comminuted fracture.


Option D-Pond fracture -Indented fracture , occurs in children due to elasticity of bones.


KEY TAKEAWAYS - Ring fractures are the most common fractures that occur due to a fall from height.

TAGLINE - EASY

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition - Page number:244,245

questions.text:
Identify the type of wound.
.
questions.solution:
• Lacerations are caused by blunt force trauma.
  • Incised looking lacetions are caused when the force is applied perpendicularly. It is seen on areas where the skin is underlying by bone such as scalp, bridge of the nose, zygoma, chin, shin, ileac crest etc. The kin get sandwiched between the causative blunt weapon and the bone. On naked eye examination, the margins appear regular; but examination under a magnifying glass helps to reveals the irregularity of the margin.

Option A- Incised wound - It is a clean-cut wound caused by a sharp cutting light weapon. Margins are regular and the edges are not abraded or bruised. Length is the greatest dimension.

Option B - Stretch laceration - It is caused when the force is applied obliquely. Due to oblique impact, the skin stretches, tears and give rise to bevelling.

Option D - Chop Wound - A chop wound is a caused by a sharp cutting/splitting heavy weapon such as an axe, heavy sickle, sword etc. Chop wounds can penetrate through skin, muscle, and even bone. The margins are regular but the edges are abraded or bruised. Tissue bridges are absent. The underlying structures may be crushed and disrupted.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- An incised-looking laceration refers to a wound that appears similar to an incision (a clean, sharp cut typically caused by a sharp object) but is actually a laceration caused by blunt force trauma. Unlike incisions, in these lacerations, the margins are irregular and caused when the force is applied perpendiculary over skin underlying by bone.

REFERENCE: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition - Page number:191

questions.text: A child was born after 8 months of father's death. Grandparents filed a case that the baby is not their son's. DNA is positive. The child is called?
questions.solution:
• A posthumous child is one who is born after the death of one or both parents. In this case, since the child was born after the father's death but is confirmed by DNA to be the biological child of the deceased father, the correct term is "posthumous child."

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A - Suppositious child:
    A suppositious child refers to a child who is falsely claimed to be the legitimate child of a deceased person, but this term is not commonly used in modern legal or medical contexts. It does not apply to the situation described.
  • Option B - Fabricated child:
    A fabricated child is not a standard term used in legal or medical contexts. It suggests falsification but is not relevant in the context of a child's legitimacy or paternity.
  • Option D - Illegitimate child:
    An illegitimate child is one born out of wedlock. However, since the issue in this case is related to the timing of birth relative to the father's death rather than marital status, "illegitimate child" is not the most accurate term here.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- A posthumous child is born after the death of one or both parents.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition - Page number:396

questions.text: 27 weeks of gestation with congenital anomalies. Whose presence is not required for authorization of MTP?
questions.solution:
• A lawyer's presence is not required for the authorization of a Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) for congenital anomalies. The primary requirement is the involvement of a medical team with specific specialists.
  • The lawyer's role typically comes into play in legal proceedings or when there are legal challenges, but not in the medical decision-making process for MTP.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A - Obstetrician:

Required: An obstetrician is essential for evaluating and managing the medical aspects of the pregnancy, including assessing the viability and risks involved with the continuation or termination of the pregnancy.

  • Option C - Pediatrician:

Required: A pediatrician's input is crucial when congenital anomalies are involved, as they provide insight into the nature and severity of the anomalies, which helps in making informed decisions about the MTP.

  • Option D - Sonologist:

Required: A sonologist, who performs and interprets ultrasound scans, plays a critical role in diagnosing congenital anomalies and assessing the gestational age of the fetus. This information is vital for decision-making regarding MTP.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The authorization process for MTP involves medical professionals such as obstetricians, pediatricians, and sonologists, but does not require a lawyer's presence.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition - Page number:401

questions.text:
A 30-year-old drowsy male was brought to the casualty. His pulse was 130/min, respiratory rate 30/min. His lab reports are given below. He showed improvement on nasogastric aspiration and administration of sodium bicarbonate, calcium gluconate, and 4-methyl pyrazole. What substance did he most likely consume?
ABG - Metabolic acidosis
Total serum calcium - 6.8 mg/dL
Blood Urea - 100 mg/dL
Creatinine - 3.4 mg/dL
Urine analysis - Calcium oxalate crystals
questions.solution:
The given scenario points towards ethylene glycol poisoning.

Ethylene glycol is converted to glyoxyaldehyde by alcohol dehydrogenase. Glyoxyaldehyde causes kidney damage.

Methanol is converted to formaldehyde by alcohol dehydrogenase. Formaldehyde causes retinal damage like blurring of vision/loss of vision.

The principles of treatment for both these conditions are the same. It predominantly involves using fomepizole or ethanol to inhibit the metabolic conversion of these relatively non-toxic alcohols to their toxic metabolites.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Ethylene glycol is converted to glyoxyaldehyde by alcohol dehydrogenase. Glyoxyaldehyde causes kidney damage.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition - Page number:583
